docs.title: TimbreForge / TimbreTouch
docs.text:
TimbreForge makes vocal timbre physically perceivable by mapping six timbre colours (Warmth, Velvet, Presence, Edge, Shimmer, Halo) to six actuator locations on the arm/hand.

Prototype + audio path

Disable noise suppression / AGC / audio “enhancements” on Windows before running. TimbreForge uses ambient-noise calibration + per-colour noise-floor subtraction, not aggressive denoising.

docs.title: Built on Vibraforge (Huang)
docs.text: Hardware and firmware are based on Vibraforge. This project contributes the software layer: mapping, calibration, GUI, workflow.

docs.title: Calibration & noise
docs.text:
TimbreForge relies on spectral energy. Any denoiser / noise suppression / AGC can distort the spectrum and break colour activation. Before running:

Disable Windows microphone Enhancements (and any “Noise suppression”, “AGC”, “Echo cancellation”).

Avoid running through apps that add suppression (Zoom/Teams/Discord/NVIDIA Broadcast) unless you explicitly want that behaviour. TimbreForge uses ambient-noise calibration + per-colour noise-floor subtraction (not “studio denoising”).

For voice capture, the usual strategy is to record a clean signal (treated room + good mic technique) rather than applying aggressive noise reduction during recording. TimbreForge follows this philosophy: keep the signal path clean, then apply light calibration for real-room robustness.

docs.title: Calibration & noise (why we do it)
docs.text:
TimbreForge uses a short ambient-noise calibration and per-colour noise-floor subtraction to reduce ghost vibrations in real rooms.

Disable denoisers first

Noise suppressors / AGC can distort spectral energy and break colour activation. Prefer a clean signal path + calibration.

docs.title: Studio note
docs.text: Typically, professional voice capture aims for a clean recording (room + mic technique) rather than heavy noise reduction during recording.

docs.title: Firmware (PlatformIO)
docs.text:
The current board firmware is stored in: - firmware/vibraforge_platformio/platformio.ini - firmware/vibraforge_platformio/src/main.cpp

Baseline

Firmware is based on Vibraforge and is normally used as-is. Only apply small edits if needed (e.g., BLE name/UUID).

docs.title: Iterations & archives
docs.text: This repo keeps archived versions to show prototype iterations and reasoning.

docs.title: Archives folders
docs.text:
• archives/V01_10_12_25/ — PoC end-to-end (voice_landmark buckets, baseline addr 0..5)
  • archives/V02_04_01_26/ — “product layer”: GUI tuning, presets, RMS monitoring, robustness
  • archives/V03_15_01_26/ — current direction (Colour mode + voice_colors) — WIP notes

See each archive folder README.md for: What/Why/How to run/What we learned.

docs.title: Recommended install (conda)
docs.text:
conda create -n timbreforge python=3.10 -y
conda activate timbreforge
conda install -c conda-forge numpy pyaudio -y
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Important (disable audio processing)
docs.text:
• Disable Windows mic Enhancements (noise suppression / AGC / echo).
  • Avoid running through Zoom/Teams suppression unless you test that specifically.

docs.title: TimbreForge/TimbreTouch is built on Vibraforge (Huang):
docs.text:
• hardware wearable + actuators + wiring
  • firmware BLE actuator control (used as-is, minor optional edits only)

docs.title: What TimbreForge adds
docs.text:
• 32 ERB bands → 6 timbre colours mapping
  • ambient-noise calibration + per-colour noise-floor subtraction
  • GUI + Live/Record/Replay reproducible workflow
